Name: Aldrex
Description: Aldrin is an organochlorine compound resulting from the Diels-Alder reaction of hexachlorocyclopentadiene with norbornadiene. A proinsecticide (by epoxidation of the non-chlorinated double bond to give dieldrin), it was widely used as an insecticide before being banned in the 1970s as a persistent organic pollutant. It has a role as a persistent organic pollutant and a proinsecticide. It is an organochlorine insecticide and an organochlorine compound.

plant_translocations.content: Data are given on the translocation and distribution of heptachlor, aldrin, and dieldrin in the corn plant. The results demonstrate that insecticide uptake in the plant varies with the time of treatment application and with the rate of plant development. The accumulation of heptachlor in the plant is low compared to aldrin and dieldrin, and conversely, the translocation is higher for heptachlor, lower for aldrin, and poor for dieldrin. In the corn kernels, up to 70% heptachlor, 31% aldrin, and 4% dieldrin are accumulated. In the plant, aldrin is metabolized into dieldrin and heptachlor into heptachlor-epoxide.
plant_translocations.reference: Polizu, A., Floru, S., & Paulian, F. (1971). Translocation and distribution of heptachlor, aldrin and dieldrin in the corn plant. Qualitas Plantarum et Materiae Vegetabiles, 20(4), 329–339. doi:10.1007/bf01104908

method.Apply Location: Injection at the level of the 3rd internode, between the leaf sheath and the stalk
method.Chemical Preparation: Emulsions containing 20% active substance of heptachlor, aldrin, and dieldrin
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Injections were made with 2 ml amounts of the product diluted at 1%. Larger amounts were injected for dieldrin due to its poorer translocation.
method.Other Information: Trials conducted with aldrin and dieldrin in 1968 at the Research Institute for Plant Protection in Bucharest, Romania. Variants contained 5 plants each, and injections were made 45, 35, 25, and 15 days before harvesting.
